Award.AwardTitle: ICOB: miRNAs and the social regulation of behavioral plasticity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Elaborate genetic networks drive complex phenotypes such as social behaviors. The recent sequencing of genomes of several social species such as the honey bee and the bumblebee provide powerful opportunities to study sociality in molecular terms. This collaborative project focuses on molecular mechanisms that contribute to the regulation of division of labor among social insects workers. Studies will investigate the role of microRNAs in regulating two systems of division of labor; age-dependent division of labor in highly social honey bees, and size-related division of labor in bumblebees. The first goal is to investigate the role of miRNAs in behavior by comparing changes in brain-enriched microRNAs that are associated with division of labor in both species. The second goal is to determine whether hormonal signals that affect division of labor in honey bees, but not bumblebees, are mediated via the action of honey bee specific microRNAs. The third goal is to establish causation between the action of conserved miRNAs and the regulation of behavioral plasticity by looking in the fruit fly, Drosophila. Both honey bees and bumblebees are economically important due to their unique roles as pollinators of diverse crops. The proposed studies will lead to a better understanding of the mechanisms that govern bee behavior in particular, and animal foraging behaviors in general.

These studies will also provide extensive training opportunities. High school and undergraduate students, including underrepresented minorities, will be trained in collecting behavioral, molecular, and physiological data, their analyses, and in scientific presentations at local and national meetings. Furthermore, this project will serve as an excellent mentorship opportunity for the postdoctoral fellow who will lead the studies. Finally, this international collaboration will foster research ties between American and Israeli research institutions, which will include reciprocal international training opportunities for personnel from both labs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term goal of this International Collaborations in Organismal Biology (ICOB) project was to investigate the possible role of non-coding micro RNAs (miRNAs) in the evolution of behavioral traits, with a specific emphasis on social behaviors in eusocial insects and mating behaviors in the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster. miRNAs are an important class of regulatory RNAs that have evolved early in the eukaryotic lineage to regulate the functions of protein-coding genes via mechanisms that are not completely understood. Remarkably, because of their molecular size, and important roles in most basic physiological processes, the sequences of the majority of animal miRNAs are conserved from the simple worm to humans. Furthermore, because individual miRNAs often regulate the translation and/or stability of multiple independent mRNAs in a single cell, they often play key roles in regulating biological stability and robustness across diverse cell types and processes. Although the role of miRNAs in developmental processes is relatively well understood, the role of specific miRNAs in conserved neural and behavioral processes remains elusive.

The approach we took to address this gap, especially in the context of social behaviors, was to investigate the role of specific miRNAs in regulating social behavior in animal models. In one set of studies, we focused on understanding the role of miRNA evolution in genomes of bee species that exhibit high levels of sociality (e.g., honey bees and bumblebees) to identify specific miRNA-encoding genes that may have been involved in the emergence of large social insect colonies. These animals are excellent models for studying mechanisms underlying social interactions because they exhibit extreme social adaptations and obligatory social lifestyle. Our analyses involved a two-step approach: First, we used genome sequence data to identify candidate genes that seem to have evolved specifically in social species but not in their solitary relatives. Second, we used state-of-the-art genomic approaches to identify miRNAs that change their expression levels in the brains of honey bees and bumblebees in association with specific social tasks they perform in their hives. This combined evolutionary and physiological approach has yielded several miRNA genes that are conserved across the studied species, which we continue to characterize in terms of their possible role in regulating the response of individuals to their social environment.

In a second set of experiments, we investigated miRNA-dependent molecular processes that are involved in the emergence of novel social traits. Specifically, we studied how miRNA gene duplications (an evolutionary process that generates an additional functional copy of a gene) may have played a role in the evolution of sex specific behaviors in Drosophila. Our studies focused on a specific duplication of a very conserved miRNA gene, which generates two very similar miRNAs. One of the genes is highly expressed in brains of both males and females while the duplicated copy seems to be expressed at a higher level in males relative to females. These findings suggested that the duplicated gene may have gained a sex-specific function. By using genetic manipulations, we were able to show that both genes are likely important for brain development, as well as sexual behaviors. However, each it also looks like that two genes have evolved a molecular division of labor, with the ‘new’ gene possibly targeting a completely new set of proteins, or a subset of proteins regulated by the ancestral gene. We are now in the process of generating novel genetic tools that will enable us to understand the molecular and physiological divisions of labor between the original and duplicated gene copies in the development of the nervous system in general, and the neuronal circuits that drive sexual behaviors in particular. This will enable us to understand better how new behavioral modules evolve, and the general role of miRNAs in neurodevelopmental processes and associated behaviors.

In addition to generating new and exciting data, this project yielded unique training opportunities. For example, the Israeli collaborator on the project was awarded an additional institutional award from Washington University, which enabled him to spend a year at the American institution as a visiting professor. During that time, he interacted extensively with members of the Ben-Shahar lab and others in our community, as well as taught a primary literature-based seminar course to upper level undergraduate and graduate students, which focused on the evolution and mechanisms of sociality. In addition, this grant supported the training of two postdoctoral fellows; one in each country. Data collected were instrumental in enabling the American postdoc to secure an academic position as an independent investigator. The project also supported independent thesis work of several undergraduate students at both the American and Israeli institutions, which now attend postgraduate PhD and Medical training programs.
